	Ability cooldown type: Refills on jump.
The Shells value defenses greatly, and your Radiant has done a large amount of work on shield systems. They can upgrade the system for cheaper than normal.
Your shields are too weak for your Radiant to help.
Your crew is successfully able to upgrade the system.
Your crew is successfully able to upgrade the system.
Your crew is successfully able to upgrade the system.
Your crew is successfully able to upgrade the system.
Your shields are too powerful for your Radiant to work on them.
data/events_storage.xml$/FTL/textList[@n: Your Radiant rolls away from you, warning that if you get too close, you might die from radiation poisoning.
Your Radiant warns that, should your hair start falling out, you see a doctor immediately for treatment against radiation.
Your Radiant explains that the Radiant race was originally genetically engineered by the Shells, but now all future Radiants are made through reproduction.
According to your Radiant, the Shells have perfected their genetic sciences, and have erased most unfavorable genes from the gene pool.
Your Radiant suggests the combination of Mind Control and a Teleporter to abduct enemy crew.
Your Radiant inquires what your favorite toxin is, based on flavor, but quickly remembers they're all fatal to you.

Shell science has come far enough to create super powerful hybrids and cure any fatal disease known to Shell kind, but your Radiant says the Shells still don't know what they look like without the actual shell.
Your Radiant thinks it would be hilarious if all of the crew rolled to their destination like they do.
Your Radiant encourages investing in hazmat suits for all of crew. Space is a dangerous place with tons of radioactive materials, such as themselves.
Your Radiant warns against staring directly at its eye, unless you like going blind.
Your Radiant explains that Shell culture allows for harmless experimentation on visitors, but unfortunately this practice has not gone over well with many other factions.
Your Radiant thinks it has one of the coolest names available. Much better than the on-the-nose Zoltan or the edgy Lost Suns.

Your Radiant has a particular distaste for the Duskbringers, finding their suicidal methods a sign of a lack of intelligence. Far be them from the immense intelligence of the Shells, using their explosive nature responsibly.
Your Radiant explains that Shells have a much higher percentage of their body composed of brains, primarily because they're basically just a head.

Your Radiant confirms it is far from the Shell Geniocracy's intentions to ally with the Coalition. Just because the Shells are distantly related to the Slugs does not mean they hold any obligation to them.
Your Radiant encourages upgrading the defenses even further. You can never have a too well-protected vessel.

Your Radiant informs you that you can cook marshmellows over it if you wish, though it's recommended you don't do so unless you also want to invent some form of mutated radioactive marshmallow monster.
data/events_storage.xml$/FTL/event[@name: What do you want to do with Alkali?

ALKALI DETAILS
	SPECIES? [Shell] SUBTYPE? [Yes]
	Subtype Details: Unique
	Inherited Stats: 200% suffocation damage, takes 90% damage from combat
	Ability (18s cooldown, 13s duration): -50 Self Health, provides a full heal to all other crew in the room. Afterwards, heals back the health lost and more at 6hp/s. While regenerating, gains 75% suffocation resistance and heals nearby friendly crew at 4hp/s.
	Ability reqs: Minimum of 55 Health, friendly crew must be in the room
	Ability cooldown type: Refills on jump.
data/events_storage.xml$/FTL/textList[@n: Alkali cannot comprehend how certain societies, such as those of the humans, have lasted so long without having yet erased genetic imperfections. Individuality is a weakness when it comes at the risk of disability according to Alkali.
Alkali wishes you to remember a very simple phrase, which he has forever immortalized in his actions. "Uniqueness is weakness", as goes the saying.

Alkali sometimes wonders what it's like living in the other districts. Not that he wishes to be in them though. Management hardly does anything anymore, the Military is constantly dealing with potential Slug invasions, and the Civilians lead uneventful meaningless lives. At least in the Science district you get to make horrible mutant creatures on occasion.

Alkali once heard stories of an alternate reality, where there lived entities known as the Mi-Go. These horrid winged fungus creatures, repulsive as they were, were incredibly advanced in science, and spliced together several successful hybrid creatures. Disgusting, but brilliant, and Alkali hopes to learn from this, and make his own monstrosities in the future. But less gut-wrenching.
"Thhhe left side of the periodic table will always be superior. Don't you go forgetting thhhhat."

"Have you ever wondered why every race builds thhheir ships somewhat resembling thhhemselves? Thhhe Orchids have plants, thhhe Slug ships look like jellyfish... what thhhe hell do Shell ships look like? A tumor?"

"How do you get by, being so... unspecialized? Are your chefs not born with inate cooking knowledge? Your police not born with thhhe instinctual desire to defend? Surely you don't let thhhhese come to be at random!"

"I wonder how I could get my hands on the formula of thhhe Free Mantis pheromones. Surely I could perfect it to not induce extreme addiction. Or maybe I'm thhhinking about thhhis thhhe wrong way. Yes! Thhhat's it! I'll make it MORE addictive! Thhhen I won't have to do anything! It'll spread naturally! It's genius!"

Alkali hates the groups of people who spit in the face of logic and turn to alternative, far more ridiculous theories. You aren't so sure how to feel, because not too long back people probably didn't think it was possible to exist in a world with sentient gas and energy, or that a massive bundle of infinite alternate realities was just waiting to be explored.

"I've heard some weird stories about some fascinating creatures I'd love to discover. Thhhe Salt Man, I think he's hiding in thhhe Guild sector somewhere. Thhhe Sirens? They've hidden thhhemselves. We know so little, but I'm certain we can dig up their origins. Fire Zoltans? I know thhhey exist... So many secrets, but I must find thhhem all!"

Alkali is busy mixing various potent chemicles in the makeshift lab in this quarters, and advises you not to get any closer. "One bump, I'll spill the chemicals. You don't want thhhat, unless you like the vacuum of space."

Alkali has very negative things to say about the other Shell district leaders. Their president, Shalkaya, he calls a smooth brained mouthpiece for whoever has the most money. Mendak, the Admiral, he calls a shortsighted halfwit who wants science to fit to his will rather than his will to fit to science. And for Nerva, the Director of the Management District, he refuses to even speak about.

"Thhhe Coalition, is a true achievement. 4 races, all deeply hating each other, yet working together for true progress!" Alkali notices you staring oddly at him. "Oh uh, bad progress of course. But progress nonthhheless!"

"You know how thhhe Morphs came to be? Well, I heard from some of my men thhhat Management was trying to get funds for Auto-ships! Damn Auto-ships are never a good idea. So, I told thhhem thhhhat I would make somethhhing even better. A species built only to work, and able to do any job imaginable! Nerva wasn't happy about that when she got wind of it. It was never my intentions to replace Management, but now I thhhink I should have..."

Alkali comes rolling out of his room at breakneck speeds. "Have any of you seen a sentient ball of acid floating around here?!" You shake your head. "Oh thhhank Newton, thhhen it hasn't escaped yet. False alarm."

Alkali shares his opinions on Arcadia. "Thhhey call thhhemselves 'Ressearch and Development' yet I don't see Arcadia popping out anythhhing othhhher thhan drones! Where's all thhhe laser sharks or, I don't know, radioactive tumor pillars." That last one strikes you as particularly... morbid, but Alkali won't go into details further than a simple "I've made some mistakes, but thhhhey're still better than anything Arcadia makes."
data/events_storage.xml$/FTL/event[@name: What do you want to do with Tyrdeo?

TYRDEO DETAILS
	SPECIES? [Leech] SUBTYPE? [Yes]
	Subtype Details: Unique
	Stats: x2.5 stun vulnerability.
	Inherited Stats: Regenerates at 6.4hp/s with a 5 second delay. Drains 1 power from enemy systems while standing in them.
	Ability (20s cooldown, 15s duration): Temporarily drains all power from the current system, but also does half combat damage and becomes immobile. Allied crew cannot sabotage the system Tyrdeo is currently draining.
	Ability reqs: System must be in room.
	Ability cooldown type: Refills on jump.
data/events_storage.xml$/FTL/textList[@n: Several of the other crew complain to you about the annoying sounds from Tyrdeo's songbird, but before you can address them the Leech jumps forward and latches onto their hand. This immediately sets a precedent - no more complaining about the bird.
You notice someone (and it's obvious who) has been hanging paintings of Tyrdeo around the ship. You'd normally throw them out, but they're very well done. Wasn't this guy a gardener?
Tyrdeo wonders if the Orchid people would mind him practicing his art on their people. If he didn't accidentally start war with the Vampweeds he could even try creating a new trend of pedal styling.
Sometimes Tyrdeo wishes he'd never gotten roped up into politics. Unfortunately, Leeches don't care much for gardening, but the alternative was becoming a turd farmer.
Tyrdeo still doesn't understand just why the Vampweed Admiral got so mad with him because of the bouquet. He assumes it has something to do with allergies.
Tyrdeo recommends that, should you ever need gardening services after this you never call him, because he sure as hell isn't going back to gardening ever again.
Tyrdeo thinks he made a wonderful president of the Eargen Republic. He isn't sure why he thinks that, but he also isn't sure why he should think otherwise either.
Tyrdeo will miss having servants at his beck and call 24/7, but at least he'll be able to buy a drone or something after this is all over.

You find a small glass display case in Tyrdeo's room with a pillow inside, presumably for holding his crown. However, since he's currently wearing it, it seems he's put an embalmed chunk of flesh as a placeholder instead.

You rush into the cafeteria where Tyrdeo is choking, his purple skin turning an even deeper shade of purple. Eventually he manages to dislodge the object, and a storm of forks and knives come pouring out of him. Guess that's where all the missing utensils went.
Tyrdeo slides past you, cheerfully humming a Leech folk-song about the dismemberment of ex-president Oertiss.
You find Tyrdeo frequently likes to give motivational speeches to the rest of the crew. They're usually self-fulfilling and full of straight up lies, but it's the thought that counts, you suppose.

You find, somehow, Tyrdeo has got himself stuck inside the special vacuum device connected to the ship's onboard toilet. Normally you'd just leave him there for a bit, but it seems unusually cruel to do so. Though, so is assigning the task of getting him free...

Tyrdeo explains he found his precious songbird inside an airtight box that had been dumped into the orbit of his home planet. It hit him in the head when falling from the sky and caused him irreversible brain damage, but the bird somehow survived.
Tyrdeo assures you he made a great president. Sure, he made some mistakes, but of all the presidents in Eargen history he was the one with the most style. Style points are everything.
data/events_storage.xml$/FTL/event[@name: What do you want to do with Tyrdeo?

ALKRAM DETAILS
	SPECIES? [Leech] SUBTYPE? [Yes]
	Subtype Details: Unique
	Stats: 100 Health, x0.7 movement speed, takes 70% damage from combat
	Inherited Stats: x1.5 stun vulnerability, 1 power drain, regenerates at 6.4hp/s with a 5 second delay.
	Aura: Doubles the power drain of fellow Leech crew. Also grants stun immunity to allied crew in the room, but is stunned longer for every allied crew in the room instead.
data/events_storage.xml$/FTL/textList[@n: Alkram doesn't seem to have the same suicidal tendencies as other Leeches. They've been replaced by homicidal tendencies instead.
You find Alkram sharpening his teeth. Because of his radial jaw, he's simply stuck a large rock in his mouth and begun to rotate it with his tongue.

You question Alkram how he manages to get his armor on every day. "The answer is simple. I don't. I eat in this armor, I sleep in this armor, I shower in this armor, I reproduce in this armor. Now stop asking me questions."

You notice that, whenever the opportunity presents itself, Alkram will answer your questions with single words. That is of course, unless you ask a question about a political topic. He has a lot to say about those.

Alkram promises that, so long as you stay true to your values, he will fight to the death for your right to defend them. You can think of some exceptions to this from stories he's told already, but you don't bring them up.

You wonder if Alkram finds it awkward helping a Federation captain considering his history during the Fed-Mantis War. Probably not, he doesn't seem to be one to feel anything other than anger and loyalty.

Alkram has a surprisingly pleasant impression of the Vampweeds. He admires their efforts to protect their own people as well as their reasonable attitude towards war, if they are sometimes short tempered. They don't act anything like the villainous Coalition that he despises.

You aren't sure how to feel about Alkram. On one hand he's stubborn and a hypocrite about many things, but he's also undoubtedly loyal to his people and he generally seems to share your opinions on factions like the Coalition and Rebellion.

Alkram wonders what would have happened if he had become president. It seems he now accepts that it almost certainly would have continued the same cycle over and over. No one wants to end up like Oertiss anyways.

Alkram doesn't talk about Tyrdeo much ever since he joined your ship, but it seems he's just eager to move on from that whole debacle. Despite this, whenever someone else mentions the former president, he's very quick to make a snarky remark.
"It doesn't say good things about the galaxy when just about every empire has a revolution brewing. Vance's little Rebellion seems to really have inspired everyone. Too bad he's a genocidal lunatic."

Alkram worries what kind of lasting influence Coalition and Theocracy occupation will have on the Republic. "Not like things can get worse than they are, but I doubt our people are strong enough to recover unless more is done to help them."
data/events_storage.xml$/FTL/event[@name: What do you want to do with your Slug?

SLUG DETAILS
	SPECIES? [Slug] SUBTYPE? [No]
	Subtype Details: Genetic, Standard
	Stats: Telepathic (sees adjacent rooms, immune to mind control), detects enemy crew
data/events_storage.xml$/FTL/textList[@n: Your Slug chuckles and tells you not to bother before you can even speak. Having telepathic crew can be very annoying.
Your Slug wishes you would remove a few of the conduct rules that you enforce on the crew. Even more preferable, all of them.
You catch your Slug trying to pilfer some scrap from the storage bay.
Your Slug half-heartedly apologizes about the slime trails they have left all over the ship.
Your Slug thinks you need to think of more creative ways to kill enemy ships.
Your Slug wishes you would visit more nebula sectors.
Your Slug tries to convince you that Anti-Bio technology is the future of advanced weaponry.
Your Slug is in the middle of a hangover, and requests you don't speak to them.
Your Slug thinks you need to relax. He hands you a pamphlet for a luxurious pleasure cruise.
Your Slug expresses his interest in the divide between the pirate clans. Personally, he's rooting for the Hackers.
Your Slug disapproves of the Rebel invasions, because they clutter up the nebulas.
Your Slug thinks you should avoid weapons that don't do lots of Bio damage.
Your Slug insults you for being ugly, and slithers away.
Your Slug wonders why anyone would ever accept a surrender.
Your Slug wants a raise.
Your Slug thinks morals are for people who like to lose wars.
You ask your Slug what they think of you. They shrug.
You catch your Slug playing around in the captain's chair.
Your Slug is sleeping. Again.
data/events_storage.xml$/FTL/event[@name: What do you want to do with your Clansman?

CLANSMAN DETAILS
	SPECIES? [Slug] SUBTYPE? [Yes]
	Subtype Details: Non-Genetic, Standard
	Stats: x0.85 move speed, 90% damage taken from combat
	Inherited Stats: Telepathic (sees adjacent rooms, immune to mind control), detects enemy crew.
	Ability (32s cooldown, 6s duration): 30 damage to all crew in the room excluding themselves, with a short delay. Will temporarily cloak, disabling movement, sabotage, combat, and repairs, but reducing damage taken from all sources to 40%.
	Ability cooldown type: Refills on jump.
data/events_storage.xml$/FTL/textList[@n: Your Clansman thinks the Federation needs a better name. Something more interesting, like "The Unified Gathering and Trade Alliance of the Species of the Galaxy, Excluding a Couple that We Don't Talk About."
Your Clansman wishes they didn't always have to wear their armor. When you ask why they do, they mumble something about layer toggling not being functional.
Your Clansman lists off a few other possible names for their faction, such as Rogues, Huntsmen, Stalkers... they keep rambling on and you aren't sure why.
Your Clansman doesn't like ships without medical facilities. Especially boarding ones that only have missile consuming weapons.
Your Clansman challenges you to find a color scheme better than the Guild ships. When you hesitate for a brief moment they assume you've given up and declare self-victory.
Your Clansman sometimes feels very strange about wearing what used to be the body of another creature, but not enough to stop doing it.
Your Clansman advises you to always go for the crew kills.
Your Clansman fancies a good horror movie from time to time. You aren't sure how that's relevant, but it's something.
Your Clansman is busy polishing their hunting rifle. You find this very strange, because you've never seen them use it in combat before.
Your Clansman tries to entertain you with a great hunting tale from their past, but you really don't care.
Your Clansman explains they only hunt for sport, or money. Considering hunting Rebels isn't as much fun as some of the more exotic races, they hope you intend to pay them at the end of the mission.
Your Clansman wishes to invest in a nice hat some day. They think it would really complement their look.
Your Clansman hopes you get the reference with the Clan Cruiser type B skin.
Your Clansman is practicing how to play the didgeridoo. You aren't really sure how they know about an Old Earth instrument like that, but it's kinda cool nonetheless.
Your Clansman has started to collect trophies from your past battles. Most of the collection just seems to be random junk metal from various ships they pilfered from the cargo.
Your Clansman is busy sleeping off a hangover in their quarters. You have no idea where they got alcohol from, but you remind yourself to inspect the ship for contraband later.
Your Clansman promises not to cry at your funeral. You have absolutely no idea what prompted such a comment, or how to feel about it.
Your Clansman tries to get you to sign some papers about organ donorship, which you ignore.
data/events_storage.xml$/FTL/event[@name: What do you want to do with your Ranger?

RANGER DETAILS
	SPECIES? [Slug] SUBTYPE? [Yes]
	Subtype Details: Non-Genetic, Elite
	Stats: x1.5 combat damage, x0.60 move speed, 80% damage taken from combat, cannot sabotage systems.
	Inherited Stats: Telepathic (sees adjacent rooms, immune to mind control), detects enemy crew.
	Ability (30s cooldown, 12s duration): 12 second stun to all enemy crew in the room and 1 ion damage to the current system, with a short delay. Will temporarily cloak, disabling movement and repairs, but reducing damage from all sources by 25%. Can still attack, but only does x1 damage.
	Ability cooldown type: Continues on jump.
data/events_storage.xml$/FTL/textList[@n: Your Ranger vows to someday catch the famous outlaw 'Nebula Red' someday. Whatever that means.
You've never seen your Ranger without its hat on. You wonder if it has to do with hiding baldness, but then you remember all Slugs are bald.
Your Ranger is polishing his rifle and humming a western tune. You don't disturb them.
Your Ranger tries to teach you how to square dance, but it doesn't go well. Mostly because they don't have feet and didn't give you any instructions on what to do.
Your Ranger shows you a medal they won when they were 7 for 'best head hunter in the galaxy'. You don't quite remember what you were doing when you were 7, but it certainly wasn't that.
Your Ranger is searching desperately for their lost hat, complaining that they aren't complete without it.
Your Ranger requests that the corpses of dead crew be stored in the cargo bay to be used as target practice for later.
Your Ranger desires to acquire a hand-held version of the infamous Anti-Bio Beam. The ammo cost will be significant, but the damage would be far greater than their current rifle.
Your Ranger recalls the time they tried to ride an Equinoid during an EHG-run rodeo. Despite their slime working as an adhesive, things didn't go very well.

Your Ranger asks you what your favorite country song is. You have a brief conversation about it until your Ranger gets heated and tries to push that "Take Me Home, Country Roads" is the greatest song ever conceived by a living creature.
Your Ranger is practicing how to throw and catch their rifle like a baton. It all goes well until the weapon discharges midair and nearly evaporates your arm.
Your Ranger explains that their armor is still made from Shells, but is dyed to match the Guild colors.
data/events_storage.xml$/FTL/event[@name: What do you want to do with your Slug Saboteur?
Have your Saboteur help with upgrading the Hacking.

SABOTEUR DETAILS
	SPECIES? [Slug] SUBTYPE? [Yes]
	Subtype Details: Non-Genetic, Elite
	Stats: x1.5 sabotage damage
	Inherited Stats: Telepathic (sees adjacent rooms, immune to mind control), detects enemy crew.
	Ability (40s cooldown, 20s duration): Cloaks. While cloaked: ignores doors, moves at x0.4 speed and is completely invulnerable to all damage from all sources. Cannot fight crew, but gains x3.0 sabotage speed. Lose 0.5x sabotage speed bonus for each enemy nearby.
	Ability cooldown type: Continues on jump.
Your Saboteur knows a thing or two about hacking. They can upgrade the system for cheaper than normal.
Your crew is successfully able to upgrade the system.
Your crew is successfully able to upgrade the system.
data/events_storage.xml$/FTL/textList[@n: Your Saboteur thinks you need to invest more in Cloaking.
Your Saboteur wonders why you would use any systems other than Hacking, Mind Control, or Cloaking.
Your Saboteur is busy drinking out of a human skull. You can still see some blood on it.
Your Saboteur looks forward to his payment after this mission is over, which he will spend on the most expensive Slug Pleasure Cruise available.
Your Saboteur explains why it is the most important crew you have.
You find your Saboteur hiding in the ventilation shaft.
Your Saboteur hates being in the line of fire, and prefers to sneak up behind its opponents and stab them.
Your Saboteur has stumbled across a series of antique old-Earth spy movies. He especially enjoys the ones about a guy called Bond.
You catch your Saboteur laughing at you. It notices you watching it, and slithers away quickly.
Your Saboteur hopes that you come across a casino during your mission. It could use a break.
You find your Saboteur playing with some strange Slug toy. When you ask what it's for, the Slug blushes and quickly hides the object.
You lecture your Saboteur on sneaking contraband onto the ship, but it tries to play innocent.
Your Saboteur once considered working aboard a cealaforming station, but it didn't like staying in the same place for too long.
Your Saboteur makes a joke about your mother, but the strange way it says it makes you question if it was a joke or not.
Your Saboteur is disappointed by the Slug Expansion Wars. It thinks Slugs belong in nebulas, and trying to invade Rock and Mantis space was a horrible idea.
Your Saboteur says that Mantis are dumb without being prompted. It won't say anything more.
Your Saboteur admits it respects the training course followed by human Soldiers.
Your Saboteur refuses to say where it received its training from.
data/events_storage.xml$/FTL/event[@name: What do you want to do with Nights?

NIGHTS DETAILS
	SPECIES? [Slug] SUBTYPE? [Yes]
	Subtype Details: Unique
	Stats: x3.0 sabotage damage, ignores doors.
	Inherited Stats: Telepathic (sees adjacent rooms, immune to mind control), detects enemy crew.
	Ability (45s cooldown, 22s duration): Cloaks and deploys a breach bomb. Breach bomb does 3 system damage, 45 crew damage (enemies only), 1 second of stun, and creates a breach. While cloaked, moves at full speed and is completely invulnerable to all damage from all sources. Cannot fight crew or repair, but gains x5.0 sabotage speed.
	Ability cooldown type: Refills on jump.
data/events_storage.xml$/FTL/textList[@n: Nights grumbles when you tell him to mop the floors of the slime trails he leaves behind. Understandably, it's quite the futile task, but you like bothering the guy.

You find yourself warning Nights for the 17th time about turning off all the lights in the ship so he can hide in the darkness and avoid responsibility. Not that it works because of his fluorescent green spots.
As Nights slithers past you, you catch a whiff of a disgusting combination of alcohol, grease, and other 'ingredients' you'd rather not mention.
You search desperately for any redeeming qualities you can think of for Nights's personality, but find literally none. At least he looks kinda cool.

Nights chuckles to himself, remarking on what an amazing name the "Knights of Nights" was. Far better than Slocknog's stupid name for his men, the "Slug Clairvoyants." What the hell does Clairvoyant even mean anyways?
Nights takes great pride in being an asshole. It's like the literal only trait he has.
You're surprised Nights hasn't tried smuggling narcotics onto the ship yet. Just because he hasn't yet though doesn't mean he won't. Remain vigilant.
Nights makes a toast in your honor then guzzles down an entire bottle of Slug beer. You doubt he really meant it in sincerity, and was just using it as an excuse to drink on the job.

Nights recalls his last trip on a Slug Pleasure Barge. He ended up catching three instances of the Gamean super-flu, a potentially life threatening virus that causes you to vomit non-stop for several hours straight. It was still worth it though according to him.

Nights warns against thinking too hard when it comes to politics. All the people want is someone who looks cool and talks smart. As long as everything you say sounds important, no one will notice if it means literally nothing.
Nights still doesn't comprehend why you chose to help him. You're starting to doubt your decisions as well, as you wipe clean another one of Nights's vomit stains from your shirt.

You check Nights's post only to find him absent. You instinctually head to his quarters and find him fast asleep in bed from a hangover. Where does this guy get his liquor from on a space ship anyways?

Nights remembers the glory days of his stint in piracy. Looking back on it, he wonders if he should have stuck with it. Killing people and burning colonies is a lot more fun than working for you, even if you still basically do the exact same things.
For once, you find Nights not drinking, smoking, or sleeping. Instead, he stands completely still, staring blankly at a wall. This guy really doesn't have a lot going for him, does he?

You inquire further into Nights's back story, hoping to learn why he acts the way he does. Strangely, literally everything about his childhood is normal as far as Slug life goes. He really is just naturally this way.
data/events_storage.xml$/FTL/event[@name: What do you want to do with Slocknog?

SLOCKNOG DETAILS
	SPECIES? [Slug] SUBTYPE? [Yes]
	Subtype Details: Unique
	Stats: x3.0 heal speed. Heals adjacent friendly crew at 2 hp/s.
	Inherited Stats: Telepathic (sees adjacent rooms, immune to mind control), detects enemy crew.
	Ability (50s cooldown, 20s duration): Stuns all enemy crew in the room for 20 seconds. While stun is active, loses Telepathy.
	Ability cooldown type: Continues on jump.
data/events_storage.xml$/FTL/textList[@n: Slocknog thinks your name sounds dumb, but understands not everyone can have as cool a name as him.
Slocknog is practicing his phonetics, hoping to learn how to no longer extend his s's. It'sssss not going ssssso well.
Slocknog dislikes the color scheme of the Knights, calling it unoriginal, bland, and tasteless. Far inferior to his hand-picked Clairvoyant yellow coloring.
Before Slocknog was king, the Slug people didn't have Elites. Actually, most factions didn't, just the Rebels. It's more or less a new trend.

Slocknog laughs suddenly, remembering something. "Thossse idiotsss sssaid I wasss the worssst vote, yet look at me now! I'm the one that made it in, not that ssstupid blue ssskin. HAH." You feel like there's some deeper meaning to this, but it's probably beyond you.
Slocknog has curled himself into a compact ball to get around faster. You don't want to ruin his hopes and dreams by telling him he has a fixed movement speed.
Slocknog considered becoming a Multiverse Renegade after stepping down as king if he didn't end up impaled by some angry statesman's electric pike. The polearm that is, not the Beam.
Slocknog wonders if working for you officially means he classifies as a "wandering hero seeking adventure."
Slocknog isn't the biggest fan of the Federation, but god damn if it pays well, then it beats being dead.
Slocknog is snoring, safely stowed away in the sanctuary of a small storage space.
Slocknog thinks the 'Kleptocracy' model is a stupid form of government. You agree, but you suspect Slocknog is only saying it out of spite.

Slocknog hates how on the nose the 'Knights of Nights' is. Not nearly as sophisticated as 'The Slug Clairvoyants'. "The besssst part," he begins, "isss who the hell actually knowsss what Clairvoyant even really meansss? The myssstery isss what makesss it geniusss!"
Slocknog is busy playing the tribal drums in his quarters.
Slocknog has a few friends in the Exotic Hunters Guild, who tell him all kinds of strange stories about creatures like "the Salt Man."
data/events_storage.xml$/FTL/event[@name: What do you want to do with the Hektar Employee?

EMPLOYEE DETAILS
	SPECIES? [Slug] SUBTYPE? [Yes]
	Subtype Details: Unique
	Inherited Stats: Telepathic (sees adjacent rooms, immune to mind control), detects enemy crew.
	Automatic Ability: Switches between Normal and Box mode.
	Ability reqs (normal): Activates below 20hp.
	Ability reqs (box): Activates above 50hp.
	Box Mode Stats: Cannot fight, sabotage, repair, or man systems. 50% damage from fire. x0.5 move speed. 10% damage from all sources.
data/events_storage.xml$/FTL/textList[@n: Your Employee can no longer feel pain, happiness, sadness, anger, or any other emotion unless completely intoxicated.
Your Employee refuses to talk to you, declaring that they are on break and thus are not obligated to interact with you.
Your Employee is trying to figure out how to use the microwave on your ship. Their source of confusion seems to come from the lack of a user manual.

Your Employee asks you if you know where the spare screw went. When you reveal that you have no idea what they are talking about, the Slug is launched into panic and quickly flees back to wherever they came from.
Your Employee demands you pay them for their time on this ship in advance. You can't help but laugh. There will be no salaries aboard this vessel.
Your Employee attempts to hide from you in a box, but fails due to the fact there are no other boxes that size in the kitchen fridge.
Without you realizing, it appears your Employee has changed the ship's alarm sound to a Hektar advertisement. You quickly change it back.

Your Employee confesses that they would undoubtedly be working for the Rebels instead for the better pay, if it wasn't for the fact they despise Slugs there. They still might try and sign up anyways later.
data/events_storage.xml$/FTL/event[@name: What do you want to do with Billy?

BILLY DETAILS
	SPECIES? [Slug] SUBTYPE? [Yes]
	Subtype Details: Unique
	Stats: Cannot heal from passive sources.
	Inherited Stats: Telepathic (sees adjacent rooms, immune to mind control), detects enemy crew.
	Ability: Switches between Normal and Box mode.
	Ability reqs (normal): Must be below 50hp.
	Ability reqs (box): Activates automatically above 50hp.
	Box Mode Stats: Cannot fight, sabotage, repair, or man. Immune to fire. x0.7 move speed. 10% damage from all sources. Passively regenerates health (10hp/s, 3s delay).
data/events_storage.xml$/FTL/textList[@n: Billy enlightens you in an old folk-tale shared amongst Hektar employees of a horrid giant Slug who lives in boxes and haunts the Hektar facilities. He won't divulge the name of this creature, strangely.
Billy is busy humming to himself the tune from a Hektar infomercial.
Billy tries to pitch a new brilliant idea he had, called the "Drone Zone". It's concerningly well put together.
Billy warns you to never inquire on the secret behind Hektar's patented Slug popcorn recipe.
Billy(tm) reveals(tm) his(tm) secret(tm) plan(tm) to(tm) trademark(tm) every(tm) word(tm). You(tm) heavily(tm) doubt(tm) anything(tm) will(tm) ever(tm) become(tm) of(tm) it(tm).
"Am I a terrible persssson? Like, isssss ssslavery THAT bad? Everyone ssseemssss to do it. Yeah, it'sss probably fine." You don't risk upsetting him by providing your own opinion.
While looking for Billy, you take a look into his quarters. A couple dozen stacks of unorganized envelopes from the Federation Revenue Service line the walls.
Billy really doesn't seem to want to talk about his brother. There must be some real bad blood between them if he won't even say his name.

You're left in shock when you walk in on Billy naked, but he doesn't seem bothered. "What'sss wrong? Literally 90% of Ssslugsss are naked conssstantly. You can't expect me to wear that ssssuit every waking moment of my life, can you?"

Billy recalls the days he used to work as a sign spinner dressed in an equinoid costume on a street corner. Well, it's not actually a real memory, he's just pretending to be humble. Billy's always been richer than you ever could be.

Billy discusses his concepts for introducing Hektar into the gaming industry. "What better way to relate to the kidsss than to add excessively aggressive and predatory loot box microtransssactions?! They'll LOVE it!"
Billy wishes he had a moustache. You aren't sure what prompted him to say this.

Billy actually vehemently hates blue and yellow. "But you ssssee, that pure unbridled hatred every time I sssee a Hektar product isss what keepsss me in the ssstate of mind to run thisss company. How can I give in to ssssomeone's heartfelt requessst for a raissse when anger issss pulssssing through my veinsss every moment? It'sss geniussss!"
data/events_storage.xml$/FTL/event[@name: What do you want to do with Sylvan?

SYLVAN DETAILS
	SPECIES? [Slug] SUBTYPE? [Yes]
	Subtype Details: Unique
	Stats: 250 health, x1.5 combat damage, takes 10% damage from fire and suffocation. Has maximum skill level. Does not lose skills from cloning.
	Inherited Stats: Telepathic (sees adjacent rooms, immune to mind control), detects enemy crew.
	Ability (45 cooldown): Deploy a Breach, Ion, and Lockdown bomb. (30 crew damage, 2 system damage, 5s stun, 3 ion damage. No friendly fire, but can Ion your systems.)
	Ability cooldown type: Continues on jump.
data/events_storage.xml$/FTL/textList[@n: You inquire why Sylvan persistently calls you stranger instead of your real name. Sylvan explains he's trying to avoid what he refers to as an 'immersion break'.
You ask Sylvan if he sells to anyone - even Rebels. Sylvan says yes, but a sly smirk suggests his other clients might not get the same preferential treatment as you.
Sylvan won't elaborate on his encounters with other Renegades, nor even the possibilities with encounters with himself. Strange, considering he normally has so many stories to tell.

You can't find Sylvan anywhere on the ship, but you suspect he might be in his quarters. Unfortunately, you wouldn't dare step foot in that room even with his permission. Some things you simply aren't meant to see.

For a brief moment you catch Sylvan leaving his quarters and spot a strangely shaped obloid object on the floor. Sylvan eyes you, and merely says "Don't assssk quesstions you don't want the anssswer to, sssstranger."

Sylvan frequently amuses the other crew with fantastical stories of mythical beasts, hidden sectors, and elusive mercenaries. You ask him about the authenticity of these stories, and he admits most of them are made up. "Ssssometimesss, ssstranger, a made up ssstory isss easier to grassssp than the truth."
You find Sylvan smoking on the bridge, away from the rest of the crew. It's strange to see him doing so, but at least he has the courtesy to do it in private.
Though you wouldn't dare enter, you can hear Sylvan speaking inside the ship restroom. Sounds like he's reciting different ways of saying "sssstranger."
"Sssstranger, have you ever heard the tale of Darth Plagueis the Wisssse? No? Ahhh too bad. What'ssss wrong, expecting ssssomething elssse?"

"Jussst ssso you know Ssstranger, you're my favorite ssstranger of all the ssstrangers I've ever had the pleasure or displeasure of meeting!" You think that's a compliment, but you aren't entirely sure.
You notice Sylvan walking around the ship without his signature outfit on. It seems so out of place, but considering most Slugs don't wear clothes at all, you suppose this would be normal to most.
You notice Sylvan's been stealing salt packets from the cafeteria. You feel like you should confront him or at least ask him what he's doing with all of them, but you know better.
Sylvan pulls you aside and hands you a small revolver with a pack of bullets crafted from fine silver. He warns: "Ussse thisss only in casssse of emergencccy, ssstranger."
You question Sylvan why he dress the way he does. He claims he stole it from another fellow, a human, during his era as a pirate. It's also where he adopted his signature "ssstranger" tik.
You find it strange Sylvan paints his ship like a pirate yet doesn't fly a pirate flag. According to him, he once did, but he's since scrubbed it away as well as all the memories attached to it.
data/events_storage.xml$/FTL/event[@name: What do you want to do with your Orchid?

ORCHID DETAILS
	SPECIES? [Orchid] SUBTYPE? [No]
	Subtype Details: Genetic, Standard
	Stats: 175% damage from fire, 80% damage from suffocation, refills oxygen at 0.5oxy/s.
	Aura: Friendly crew in the same room gain 20% maximum health and healing speed, and 20% repair speed.
data/events_storage.xml$/FTL/textList[@n: Your Orchid wants to start a petition to prevent plant cruelty in Federation Sectors.
Your Orchid thinks life support systems are overrated.
Your Orchid asks if you have any extra water you can lend them.
Your Orchid expresses distaste for regular Missile Launchers, and requests you get more Kernel Launchers.
Your Orchid talks about its extreme fear of fire.
Your Orchid longs for real sunlight, and not just the artificial lights on the ship.
Your Orchid complains about your rule against them hypnotizing the other crew.
Your Orchid is busy decorating its quarters with vines.
Your Orchid wonders why you wouldn't vent all of the unnecessary rooms on the ship.
Your Orchid wishes it were stronger.
Your Orchid complains that one of its petals is wilting.
Your Orchid wonders what it's like to have flesh.
You ask about the biological history of the evolution of Orchids. According to them, the first organism on their planet with brains were plants.
Your Orchid encourages that you become strictly carnivorous.
Your Orchid wants you to visit less hostile sectors.
Your Orchid wishes you had higher quality water aboard the ship.
Your Orchid wonders what it's like to live alone as the Separatists do. They want to try it some time.
Your Orchid wants to build a greenhouse aboard the ship.
Your Orchid wants more Zoltans on the ship, because they give off light.
data/events_storage.xml$/FTL/event[@name: What do you want to do with your Orchid Chieftain?
Have your Chieftain help with upgrading the Life Support.

CHIEFTAIN DETAILS
	SPECIES? [Orchid] SUBTYPE? [Yes]
	Subtype Details: Genetic, Elite
	Stats: 130 health, 300% damage from fire, immune to suffocation, refills oxygen at 2oxy/s.
	Aura: Friendly crew in the same room gain 25% maximum health and healing speed, and are immune to suffocation.
Your Chieftain is practically their own life support system. They can upgrade the system for cheaper than normal.
Your crew is successfully able to upgrade the system.
Your crew is successfully able to upgrade the system.
Your crew is successfully able to upgrade the system.
data/events_storage.xml$/FTL/textList[@n: Your Chieftain expresses their extreme fear of fire. They really, really don't like fire.
Your Chieftain has no explanation as to why they can't suffocate. At least, not scientifically.
Your Chieftain brags about being able to outcompete a Lanius when it comes to oxygen.
Your Chieftain complains about its wooden limbs being too stiff.
You attempt to speak with your Chieftain, but after a few minutes of terrible, mistranslated plant puns you decide to make like a tree and leaf.
Your Chieftain is busy trimming their roots. They seem really embarrassed about it and plead for you to leave.
Your Chieftain is deathly afraid of vegetarians. They advise you try being exclusively carnivorous.
Your Chieftain is attempting to (poorly) play a set of tribal drums.
Your Chieftain has started a collection of alien plants from different worlds in their private quarters.
Your Chieftain likes the strawberry color scheme for Orchid ships the best.
Your Chieftain recommends using kernels as an alternative to standard ammunition.
Your Chieftain has started hanging small ornaments of alien design on their leaves. You'll never understand Orchid fashion, but at least it makes them happy.

Your Chieftain explains that, despite being plants, the Orchids cannot sustain themselves entirely from photosynthesis because of how complex their biology is. This is why they have evolved to be carnivorous.
Your Chieftain tries to get into a conversation about garden politics, but you're not interested.
Your Chieftain doesn't make good conversation, as they rarely speak.
Your Chieftain complains that the other crew have been referring to it as a "house plant." It's not sure what this means, but it assumes it's derogatory.
Your Chieftain wishes people would stop referring to it as a "free oxygen power-bar"
Your Chieftain is busy trying to bandage up a wound dripping with sap.
data/events_storage.xml$/FTL/event[@name: What do you want to do with your Phantom?

PHANTOM DETAILS
	SPECIES? [Ghost] SUBTYPE? [No]
	Subtype Details: Genetic, Standard
	Stats: 80 Health, 2.0x sabotage speed, x0.8 movespeed, immune to suffocation and fire, ignores doors.
data/events_storage.xml$/FTL/textList[@n: The ability of your Ghost to slip through doors concerns you. It may be time to check the seal on them again...
Your Ghost is impressed with how well you've managed to keep your ship in one piece. They tell you not to worry. If the ship explodes, they'll continue to live, even if you don't.
Your Ghost thinks the ship isn't crowded enough. He won't be satisfied until it's impossible to move through the ship without bumping shoulders with someone else.
Your Ghost wonders if it would be cool to have AI holograms as crew. You think it would be incredibly lame and boring. Which is why it won't ever happen. Probably.
Your Ghost comments that you can never have too many Ghosts on your ship.
You try to catch up with your Ghost, but they always manage to slip past through the doors before you can open them.
Your Ghost is trying to tear the paint off the walls of his quarters, so that he can see the comforting internals of the ship that it is so used to.
Your Ghost doesn't understand the concept of gender. It tries to rationalize why other species would have different biology for different roles. How truly inefficient.
You try to teach your Ghost to dance, but it can't quite get the moves right. It blames its gaseous nature.
Your Ghost wants to someday be an architect, so that it can try and bring broken ships into style.
Your Ghost contemplates the meaning of life. They eventually give up, declaring it pointless.
Your Ghost doesn't want to socialize. What an introvert...
Your Ghost attempts to jump out from behind the door and scare you. You fake your surprise. If only they hadn't done this 20 times before in the last hour...
Your Ghost claims to be made of "special gas" which separates it from regular ghosts. You have no idea how that works, but you aren't going to argue.
Your Ghost was once accused of using "noclip" by a Slug hacker, a phrase which it still doesn't fully comprehend.
Your Ghost hopes you understand that it is floating, and not flying. There is a tremendous difference.
Your Ghost is glad that they can phase through certain surfaces, because else-wise they could constantly hit their head on the threshold of every door as they are floating.
Your Ghost sometimes wishes it could feel, or properly talk, or do anything other than be an anthropomorphous blob of gas.
Your Ghost has a particular taste for Old Earth music from the 16th century. This is probably a reference.
Your Ghost wants to learn how to stand some day. Maybe if you teach it, it'll try and teach you how to float. You don't have the heart to tell them that'll never work.
Your Ghost hopes they don't have too terrible an odor, because they can't smell things. You can only slightly hear them, because you're standing on the other side of the room to avoid the smell.
Your Ghost's anatomy remains a mystery to this day. Maybe you just aren't meant to think that hard about it.
You attempt to speak to your Ghost, but they simply pass through you on their way past.
Your Ghost explains they can't actually move through solid matter, but rather anything that isn't air tight. No idea why they can move through the doors of a spaceship though.

Your Ghost recommends not standing too close to it unless you like the smell of rotting souls. Not that it has anything to do with the supernatural, that's just the unpleasant smell created by their gases.
Your Ghost wonders if there's life after death. If there is, probably not for them, because they're just sentient gas.
Your Ghost wonders why you don't just steal other ships when yours is destroyed, much like the Ghost Vagabonds usually do. You really aren't sure why either.
Your Ghost pleads that you never open the airlocks with them inside, because it will send them flying out into the abyss of space. They won't die of course, but chances are you'll never find them.
Your Ghost suggests that, should you dismiss them, you not throw them out into space, but rather dump them into a planet's atmosphere so that they at least have somewhere to land.
Your Ghost hopes to someday assimilate with a gas giant when they're older.

data/events_storage.xml$/FTL/textList[@n: Dessius reads you a few lines from a poem he wrote. Halfway through he starts crying, and it's clear its a very emotional piece to him. It's just a shame you'll never know why, because you forgot to bring your translator and have no idea what the poem says.

You ask Dessius why the Ghosts all speak so... fancy. "Ah, the answer is most simple. Have you ever heard a Mantis, those violent insectoids, and their choppy barbaric language? Well to themselves it must sound brilliant and smooth! But to us, it sounds imbecilic. Well, much a same effect occurs on your translators with our static."
You finally work up the courage to ask Dessius how Ghost anatomy works, but he just breaks out laughing. "AHAHAHAHAHHAHAHAHAHAHAHAH, my friend don't be silly!" and floats away.
Dessius sometimes wonders what he must look like to people who haven't a clue what the Ghosts are. A floating set of armor surrounded by some pink gas isn't a very usual sight.
Dessius wonders what a 'samurai' is, and why he keeps seeing people compare him to one.

Dessius humors the silly names that explorers and translators have given the Ghosts and their various titles. A better translation of 'Prime Reaper' would be Eldane Prodalccius. But where's the fun in that?

Dessius comes from a long line of long-named Ghosts. The Dynasty has only had 16 Prime Reapers in its time, and Dessius's bloodline has been in charge since the 7th Reaper. A Ghost will usually divide 10 to 12 times before they finally dissipate, which can make choosing an heir difficult.

Dessius has little worries about the seemingly problematic overpopulation issues that the Dynasty experiences. "Every year thousands of the most devoted zealots line up for their ceremonious plunging into the heart of the nebula to become one with the cosmos. It's wide scale population control without my own fingers ever once needing lifting."

Dessius confesses that his full name is actually "Anglicus Dessius Probission-Taledemy." For the longest time he assumed he had the longest name around, until he heard word of some Rockman cult leader who rivaled even him.

Dessius worries greatly about CICA's Auto invasion and the sphere of influence that the troublesome AI is slowly growing. You try to explain CICA isn't actually sentient, just controlled by Vance, but Dessius won't listen.
"Have you ever laid sight upon a ship such as the Dreadnaught from earlier? Nay, neither have I. Mine conscience struggles to comprehend what horrors might lie in the devilish mind of Vance."

"Stay at my side, friend, and the swift strike of my sword shall prove the setting sun that none before us shall last lest they fall to their knees and cry the holy words of mercy which appease us!" You aren't even sure if you know what that means, but it sounds endearing.
data/events_storage.xml$/FTL/event[@name: What do you want to do with your Lanius?

LANIUS DETAILS
	SPECIES? [Lanius] SUBTYPE? [No]
	Subtype Details: Genetic, Standard
	Stats: Drains oxygen at 0.5oxy/s, immune to suffocation.
data/events_storage.xml$/FTL/textList[@n: You can't find your Lanius anywhere. You have to hope it isn't busy feasting on some important part of the ship.
Your Lanius tries to convince you that scrap makes an excellent, nutritious meal.
Your Lanius isn't sure how to hold a conversation. Your discussion mostly consists of you asking questions and it responding with one word answers that usually don't pertain at all to what you asked.
Your Lanius requests that if it is ever killed, you are to melt its corpse into metal and turn it into a Flak Cannon.
Your Lanius asks why you won't just turn off the oxygen. You try to explain that other crew need to breathe, but it just doesn't comprehend.
Your Lanius makes no attempt to speak in a comprehensive language, and instead makes garbled noises that your translator can't even begin to convert.
Your Lanius wants to return to a nomadic life once this mission is over.
Your Lanius asks if it can shake your hand, understanding it's a symbol of friendship between humans. You shake its sharp blade arm cautiously, though you still end up cut.
Your Lanius doesn't understand why some people eat meat and plants when there is an unlimited supply of junk to feast upon.
You ask if your Lanius will help update your translator to understand its language better, but have to stop when it tries to eat the device.
Your Lanius requests that you buy more Flak Cannons, and give it any of the left over ammunition for it to eat.
Your Lanius requests that it is paid in space junk instead of Federation currency when this mission is over.
Your Lanius doesn't care if it's on the good side or the bad side, as long as there's scrap for it to eat.
Your Lanius doesn't understand loyalty. It'll obey whoever is feeding it. You make a mental note to never let your Lanius negotiate with the Rebels.
Your Lanius doesn't understand why so many people dislike its species.
Your Lanius advises you keep it away from the other crew, just in case the respirators malfunction.
Your Lanius asks why you won't just put on a space suit. You aren't sure of the answer yourself.
Your Lanius doesn't care to talk. It briefly asks if you have anything for it to eat before going back to sitting completely still.
Your Lanius hopes you will put more time into salvage missions, so that it will have more junk to eat.
data/events_storage.xml$/FTL/event[@name: What do you want to do with your Augmented Lanius?

AUGMENTED DETAILS
	SPECIES? [Lanius] SUBTYPE? [Yes]
	Subtype Details: Genetic, Standard
	Stats: 110 Health, x1.2 sabotage damage, provides 1 power. When not at full health, decays at 0.5hp/s until healed back to full again.
	Inherited Stats: Drains oxygen at 0.5oxy/s, immune to suffocation.
	Ability (25s cooldown, 8s duration): Does 1 hull and 1 system damage, and creates a breach in the current room (can damage player ship as well). Heals back to full health immediately. Enters boosted mode temporarily. While boosted, move speed, combat damage, and repair speed are x2.0, sabotage damage is x2.4, and drains oxygen at 2oxy/s. Does not decay while boosted.
	Ability cooldown type: Continues on jump.
data/events_storage.xml$/FTL/textList[@n: Your Augmented lives in constant fear that they're going to randomly disintegrate. It's not a healthy way to live.
You catch your Augmented trying to eat the hull. You have to forcibly remove them from it without creating a breach.
Your Augmented hungers for scrap. That's all they have to say.
Your Augmented boasts about having the coolest color scheme of any faction. Or at least, so they claim.
Your Augmented wonders why there is such a high concentration of Ancient ruins within the Recovery Site, but nowhere else.
All your Augmented can talk about is scrap. Still more interesting than the kind of conversations a human could start.
Your Augmented begins to list off a long list of elements that its body are composed of. You don't recognize any of them.
Your Augmented has plugged a holopad charger into itself. You aren't sure how it cut a charging port into its body, but you won't complain about free power.
Your Augmented can feel the power running through its body, and it feels funny. He can't stop vibrating either.
Your Augmented advises you don't use its ability on the ship unless necessary. Or if you're feeling suicidal.
Your Augmented promises to only eat small sections of the ship, never large ones. Unless it is really really hungry.
Your Augmented sometimes regrets its diet, but it won't go back. Mostly because it's not sure what kind of metal normal Lanius are made of anyways.
You ask if your Augmented can fully update your translator, but it shakes its head. Apparently, the Lanius just speak that way normally.
Your Augmented explains their language is different from that of normal Lanius, composed of portions of both the Swarm dialect as well as large chunks learned from reading Ancient inscriptions.
Your Augmented has accidentally turned off the gravity field in the bathroom, and is now stuck floating in the air. You almost make the same mistake but carefully step out and get to work fixing it.
Your Augmented is practicing the trumpet. It is struggling to do so, as it both does not breathe and also melts the instrument whenever it touches it.
Your Augmented hopes you won't ever confuse it for a storage augment. You assure it that you won't make such a mistake.
Your Augmented tries to explain that scrap is actually a broad term for different kinds of junk, but you aren't listening. As far as you're concerned, it's just currency.
Your Augmented wishes it could cuddle instead of stabbing people's eyes out.
data/events_storage.xml$/FTL/event[@name: What do you want to do with The Anointed?

ANOINTED DETAILS
	SPECIES? [Lanius] SUBTYPE? [Yes]
	Subtype Details: Unique
	Stats: 200 Health, x1.5 sabotage damage, provides 2 power. When not at full health, decays at 1.2hp/s until healed back to full again.
	Inherited Stats: Drains oxygen at 0.5oxy/s, immune to suffocation.
	Ability (25s cooldown, 15s duration): Does 2 hull and system damage, and creates a breach in the current room (can damage player ship as well). Heals back to full health immediately. Enters boosted mode temporarily. While boosted, move speed, combat damage, sabotage damage, and repair speed are x4.0, drains oxygen at 4oxy/s, and provides 4 power. Does not decay while boosted.
	Ability cooldown type: Refills on jump.
data/events_storage.xml$/FTL/textList[@n: The Anointed promises they are not a cult leader. They advise you not to ask about it any further.
The Anointed informs you that "The Anointed" is their real name that they were given at birth. It's only pure coincidence that they ended up where they are now.
The Anointed advises you avoid making any racist allusions about the Lanius or Ancient hierarchies.
The Anointed repeatedly reminds you to always capitalize the "The" at the start of their name.
The Anointed is very picky about what scrap they'll eat. You can't understand caring when you're already eating space trash, but to each his own.
The Anointed swallows a massive chunk of scrap metal right in front of you, then walks away. You aren't sure if you just walked in at a bad time or if they were trying to make a point.
The Anointed appreciates you saving them, and offers you a small trinket made out of its own body matter. You warily accept it, and put it in the farthest corner of your room that you can.
The Anointed shares a story of when they ate an entire Dynasty warship before they became the leader of the Augmented. You're glad to have her on your side.
The Anointed calls dibs on everything in the cargo bay, should the mission be abandoned.
The Anointed is enjoying a nice glass of liquid magma in their quarters. You decide not to intrude on them.
The Anointed is busy sharpening their blades. They discourage you come any closer until the process is finished.
You find yourself warning the Anointed about eating the fuel cells for the 30th time since they joined your crew after you catch them in the act yet again.
The Anointed is thinking of new synonyms to describe itself, and finds the thesaurus to be largely unhelpful.
The Anointed isn't sure how to remove the lights stuck along its body, or how they got there in the first place.
data/events_storage.xml$/FTL/event[@name: What do you want to do with The Beacon Eater?

BEACON EATER DETAILS
	SPECIES? [Lanius] SUBTYPE? [Yes]
	Subtype Details: Unique
	Stats: 200 Health, x2.5 sabotage damage, instantly drains oxygen
	Inherited Stats: immune to suffocation.
	Can consume beacons when there is an opportunity for it. This will usually provide additional fuel and scrap, but has a 25% chance of backfiring and leaving you stranded, boosting the fleet by a jump.
data/events_storage.xml$/FTL/textList[@n: The Beacon Eater once met the leader of a second swarm somewhere long long ago. Someday they'll meet again, and probably kill each other.
The Beacon Eater has gone by many nicknames, but his all time favorite is "baconator."

The Beacon Eater has trapped himself accidentally at many a beacon before. Fortunately, the Lanius move around so much, it's not too long until they find him again. The longest he's ever been stranded was a year, no big deal.
The Beacon Eater's diet is insatiable. It's a high price, but a worthy one when it means he gets to look so damn cool.
The Beacon Eater explains the process of designing his own form. The stage it struggled the most over was the eyes. There was over 20 options at one point!
The Beacon Eater does not exclusively eat beacons, contrary to what his name suggests. Sometimes he eats a ship or two instead.
data/events_storage.xml$/FTL/event[@name: What do you want to do with your Lanius Welder?

WELDER DETAILS
	SPECIES? [Lanius] SUBTYPE? [Yes]
	Subtype Details: Non-Genetic, Elite
	Stats: 110 Health, x1.25 repair speed, drains the health of drones and metaloids (excluding other Lanius) at a rate of 4hp/s. Drains oxygen at 0.525oxy/s.
	Inherited Stats: Immune to suffocation.
	Ability (30s cooldown, 15s duration): Will regenerate health at 4hp/s and drain oxygen at 4oxy/s, but move at 0.3x speed.
	Ability cooldown type: Refills on jump.
data/events_storage.xml$/FTL/textList[@n: Your attempts at communicating with your Welder fail. You aren't even sure if the gibberish they're making is a real language or actually incomprehensible nonsense.
Contrary to their name, your Welder has few skills when it comes to actual welding. They can however make a nice souffle.
Your Welder explains that its red color comes from rust, which naturally develops on their bodies. It's often considered a status symbol in Lanius society.
It's fortunate that metal beings don't have body odor, because you notice that your Welder has not showered once the entire mission.
Your Welder requests that any unused resources from the mission are given to it so that it may have a victory banquet.
You lecture your Welder about eating the ship after catching it trying to eat some electronics labeled as "very important, do not touch".
Your Welder offers to be used as a projectile if ever deemed necessary. They seem very eager about it, actually.
Your Welder wonders why so many races end with "man", yet Lanius are not referred to as "Metalmen".
You accidentally brush against the Welder, cutting yourself on the spikes. They apologize, and recommend you clean the wound immediately.

You enter your Welder's private chambers and are startled by the floating pair of glowing eyes in the darkness. You quickly turn on the lights, and remind yourself you can always bring your Welder along in case the flashlight runs out of batteries.
Your Welder finds comfort in working in close-quarters. It's unfortunate that other races don't feel the same, not eager to be impaled on the sharp spikes.
Your Welder requests assistance in sharpening the spikes along their body. You awkwardly agree to assist.
Your Welder requests some oil or grease to lubricate its rusty joints.
Your Welder compliments you on your military prowess, and your ability to employ strategies that don't involve launching the crew out of a Flak launcher to eat the enemy ship.
Your Welder looks forward to the next mass-hibernation of the Lanius race, though they will miss the action of serving on a ship like yours.
Your Welder refuses to explain the science behind how Lanius drain oxygen.
Your Welder boasts about the efficiency of its oxygen draining abilities, claiming that it takes a full squad of Orchids to outcompete it.
You cannot find your Welder, and the computer informs you they took a brief bathroom trip out in the vacuum of space.

Your Welder dislikes the constant attention that the Lanius race receives from nosy researchers, biologists, cultists, mechanics, journalists, government officials, tax collectors, and various other occupations that you can't fathom how they relate.
data/events_storage.xml$/FTL/event[@name: What do you want to do with your Crystal?

CRYSTAL DETAILS
	SPECIES? [Crystal] SUBTYPE? [No]
	Subtype Details: Genetic, Standard
	Stats: 125 Health, x0.8 combat damage, 50% suffocation resistance
	Ability (38s cooldown, 12s duration): Locks down the current room. Takes 7 damage and uses 1 ability charge.
	Ability reqs: Health must be above 20
	Ability cooldown type: Refills a charge on jump. Can hold 2 charges.
data/events_storage.xml$/FTL/textList[@n: Your Crystal hopes you visit more Rock Sectors so that it may see more of its cousins.
Your Crystal is fascinated by geology. It has collected several rocks and crystals from foreign planets throughout its journeys.
Your Crystal knows many of its friends decided to stay behind in the old Crystal Homeworlds. It left after being unable to tolerate the persistent waves of pioneers coming to explore.
Your Crystal thinks the war between the Federation and Rebellion is pointless, and doesn't understand why humans don't just isolate themselves before they start more wars.
Your Crystal encourages you to install more layers of protection on the hull.
Your Crystal advises you to avoid using missiles due to their cost inefficiency.
Your Crystal has barricaded themselves in their quarters with a thick layer of crystals. You're unable to get through.
Your Crystal wonders why you need doors when you have him to lock out intruders.
Your Crystal asks if you have any secret abilities lying in wait.
Your Crystal requests that you designate a room specifically for growing crystals in.
Your Crystal tries to explain to you the process of growing crystals, but you're lost early on.
Your Crystal thinks you are dignified enough for it to be satisfied with having you in command.
Your Crystal wonders what it would be like to command its own fleet.
Your Crystal disapproves of the Rebellion ever since they invaded the original Crystal Homeworlds in large numbers.
Your Crystal wants to try building an entire ship out of its own freshly grown crystals someday.
Your Crystal thinks you need to diversify your crew even more.
Your Crystal politely requests that you not talk to it.
Your Crystal thinks proper manners are the most important thing in the galaxy.
Your Crystal secretly confesses it misses all of the shrines worshiping its kind in the Rock Sacred Grounds before the Lost Suns converted it into their Stronghold.
data/events_storage.xml$/FTL/event[@name: What do you want to do with your Sentinel?
Have your Sentinel help with upgrading the doors.

SENTINEL DETAILS
	SPECIES? [Crystal] SUBTYPE? [Yes]
	Subtype Details: Non-Genetic, Elite
	Stats: 135 Health, x0.65 move speed, 60% suffocation resistance.
	On Death: 15 damage to enemy crew, locks down the room
	Ability (5s cooldown, 12s duration): Locks down the current room. Takes 7 damage and uses 1 ability charge.
	Ability reqs: Health must be above 20
	Ability cooldown type: Refills 4 charges on jump. Can hold 8 charges.
Your Sentinel knows a lot about blockades and fortifications, which extends even to door systems. They can upgrade the system for cheaper than normal.
Your crew is successfully able to upgrade the system.
Your crew is successfully able to upgrade the system.
data/events_storage.xml$/FTL/textList[@n: Your Sentinel is busy making a defensive barricade in the bathroom, and won't let anyone in.
Your Sentinel breaks off a shard from their back and hands it to you as a gift. It promises more of them in a few hours once they grow back.
Your Sentinel hopes to some day return to the Crystalline Origins, and fight off the scavengers who stole their homelands from them.
Your Sentinel's given purpose in its society was to protect the Crystalline people. By serving aboard your ship instead, their only hope at redemption is to defeat the Rebellion or die trying.
Your Sentinel doesn't particularly approve of the oppressive Rock Elders, but it also doesn't mind being worshipped as a god.
Your Sentinel claims to have read through the entirety of the Rock Holy Texts before, and was surprised by how many spelling mistakes it had. Oh, and also that everything in it was a lie.
Your Sentinel advises you never inquire as to where or how the Crystal produce the shards for their lockdown ability.
Your Sentinel is busy guarding one of the doorways. When you attempt to say hello and pass through, they stop you and request to see your ID.
Your Sentinel is sleeping. When you accidentally wake them, they grumpily inform you that their slow metabolism requires the Crystals to sleep for much longer than an average organism.
Your Sentinel promises to defend the ship for as long as it is still a ship. However, if it becomes something else, like a train or a car, it can't make any promises.

Your Sentinel is looking for possible call-signs to go by. Their current ideas are "guardian", "protector", or "defenser". That last one they claim has to be pronounced that way as "defender" is already taken by the Engi.
Your Sentinel attempts to argue that Crystalline Vengeance isn't completely useless. However, their primary point is simply that "it sells for a good bit of scrap".
Your Sentinel demands that it not be used as a suicide bomber like a Zoltan.
Your Sentinel is attempting to work on running faster, but complains about being limited by "the game".
Your Sentinel hates foreigners. They aren't sure why, or who counts as a "foreigner" anymore, but that's what their leaders tell them, so that's what they must believe.
Your Sentinel sometimes feels the Crystalline Empire can be as restrictive as the Rock Theocracy, limiting the travel of its citizens and forbidding outside influence.
Your Sentinel wonders what it would be like to be an actual god, rather than a mortal creature worshiped by a bunch of ignorant Rock people.
data/events_storage.xml$/FTL/event[@name: What do you want to do with A55?

A5540L3 DETAILS
	BLUEPRINT? [Doctor]
	Stats: 150 Health, 1.5x combat damage, x0.6 move speed, repairs self at x2.0 speed in the drone bay, heals friendly crew at 2hp/s, can man systems at lvl2 efficiency.
data/events_storage.xml$/FTL/textList[@n: A55 is debating with some of the other crew about the usefulness of doctor drones. Obviously, he has a very biased take on them.
"Yo ho ho, fiddledeedee, being a pirate is 103!" A55 drives past shouting this, before stumbling over a set of stairs and crashing into the engine room.
A55 wonders when he'll be able to ditch his paper hat in favor of one that doesn't disintegrate when wet.
"Arg, matey! Lass. Ladey. Mate? No... Lad. Er... Yo ho ho." A55 rolls away.
You question A55 where his unfortunate name came from. "It's a joke, lad. It spells asshole. I didn't think you were stupid."
A55 is practicing swinging around his buzzsaw. It's a massive safety hazard, but you can't get close enough to tell him this without being struck. It's that bad.
You debate the ethical controversy over whether or not A55 deserves his own quarters aboard the ship. Frankly, he still seems fine living next to the toilet.

A55 seems to evade the question any time you ask him just how he came into control of the pirate town. You manage to get a little out of this, but he stops during a tale about installing an oral cavity on his model.
You find A55 powered off in the middle hallway. Fairly problematic that you have to keep powering him off to do other things, and you hope this doesn't have any long lasting consequences.

data/events_storage.xml$/FTL/textList[@n: "Loo! Yu coo loo spog!" Your Morph begins to shout gibberish at you, and you quickly walk away.
You search around for your Morph but can't find them anywhere. They've probably disguised themselves to hide from you as a joke, so you give up.
Sometimes you wonder whether the Morphs actually have a language or are saying completely incoherent garbage.
You try to give your Morph a tablet for communicating with, but instead of typing on it, they morph to match it. It's a miracle these guys listen to you at all.
Your Morph giggles excitedly and transforms into a copy of yourself. You're both amazed and terrified.
You find your Morph has consumed one of the ship's fire extinguishers whole, and spend the next 10 minutes trying to wrestle it out from inside of the blob before it dissolves.
The fact the Shells were able to create a sapient species like the Morphs is incredible, but you just wish they gave them the ability to speak properly.
You take some time tinkering with your translator to comprehend the Morph language, but it turns up nothing. You'll just have to keep trying.
You wonder if cutting the Morph in half would create two separate Morphs or just kill it. You're very curious, but not willing to risk it.

Morph anatomy is truly a mystery to you. As far as you can tell, they have no blood, organs, or nervous system yet are sapient living creatures. All the same, this is a galaxy of beings made of pure energy, gas, and trillions of nanobots. A grey amorphous blob is the least of your worries.
You're glad the Morphs aren't hostile non-sapient creatures, as you watch it devour a mound of flesh of some alien creature that found its way into the cargo hold.

Various items of garbage left around the ship by your crew have begun to attach to your Morph as it rolls around the ship. You'd imagine that'd have to be rather painful, but the Morph doesn't seem to mind. You aren't even sure if they can feel pain.
You wonder what your Morph is thinking. You assume they have to be able to think to be as intelligent as they are, but honestly you have no idea.
You're dying with curiosity to know the mystery of how the Morphs work, but alas its a mystery that will likely go unsolved for all time.
